Q: ASP.NET WebForms still loads old jQuery from ScriptResource.axd after upgrading to jQuery 3.7.1 A:

ScriptResource.axd isn't a sign of problems. It's the endpoint that serves the application's combined and minified scripts. That's what will serve the updated jQuery scripts.

The real security problem is that ASP.NET WebForms is still used - that's obsolete technology, abandoned by Microsoft itself.

Since ASP.NET 4.5, released in 2012 you can upgrade jQuery through NuGet by upgrading to the latest version of the AspNet.ScriptManager.jQuery and AspNet.ScriptManager.jQuery.UI.Combined packages.

As the article ASP.NET 4.5 ScriptManager Improvements in WebForms explains :

The default templates for WebForms ship with the following packages “AspNet.ScriptManager.jQuery” and “AspNet.ScriptManager.jQuery.UI.Combined”. These packages make it easier to bring in jquery and jqueryUI libraries and also register them with the ScriptManager.

The rest of the article explain the registration.

The latest version of these packages, 3.7.1, released in 2024, should target jQuery 3.7.1.

That said, all these technologies are obsolete, and many parts are abandoned. The Ajax Control Toolkit for example was abandoned by Microsoft in 2014 and and maintained by DevExpress in 2014 until 2020, when its last version came out. After that it was abandoned and archived as well.

Q: Printing numbers in a row without using string A:

I copied this answer from Moinuddin Quadri, but instead of using math.log to count digits, I used a while loop.

def get_my_number(n):
    my_num = 0
    for i in range(1, n+1):
        temp = i
        digits = 0
        while temp > 0:
            temp //= 10
            digits += 1
        my_num = my_num * (10 ** digits) + i
    return my_num

print(get_my_number(99))
